WENCESLAO PAREJA, M.D.
CLINICIAN
At sea.
September 15,1919.
My dear Carter:
div1.p:
I am writing on the Peruvian cruiser “Lima” running up the coast
to Payta. Payta is the port of Piura about thirty miles back from the coast.
They are having there quite a sharp attack of yellow fever. They have had in
the past two months about 117 cases, with 20 deaths. The conditions are most
unusual. Piura is in a desert, arid country, having very little communication
with Guayaquil, no known yellow fever for fifty years, though back in the forties
it was known to have occurred here.

I wish you and Dr Guiterras were with me to give me your advisce on
the subject. Guiterras could not come on account of Mrs Guiterras' serious
illness, and Paerry told me that you were sick and thought you should not go
even if you were willing. How would you feel about going the next trip, say
about January first?

Connor is in charge at Guayaquil and has done very good work. They
have not had yellow fever there during June, July and August. I expect to get to
Nicaragua about the middle of October. Lyster is looking after the yellow
fever occurring in this region. I expect to get home about December 1st.

Please give my love to Mrs Carter and Laura. I hope you are all
right again.
div1.closer:
W. C. Gorgas Dr. Henry R. Carter.
Baltimore.
